item.title: How to Study for the AWS Certified Solutions Architect Associate Exam
item.author: trevor.ryan.mccormick@gmail.com (Trevor McCormick)
item.description: Background There is no better preparation than hands-on experience with AWS. Before I attempted this certification exam, I had about two years of experience working across AWS, primarily using services to build my website and handle data ingestion and warehousing processes at work. I had drawn out some simple architecture documents up to this point, and I could generally describe what was happening. However, I knew that in order to pass the exam, I would need to strengthen my understanding of services I was already familiar with (S3, RDS, IAM), and spend a significant amount of time learning the ones I did not use day to day (VPC, Route53, Networking, etc).

item.title: How To Query PostgreSQL in AWS RDS with Python
item.author: trevor.ryan.mccormick@gmail.com (Trevor McCormick)
item.description: In this post I’ll walk through: how to create a public PostgreSQL instance in RDS using free-tier how to create a table and load it with data from a csv file how to query data from that table using psycopg2 PostgreSQL on RDS The only thing you have to do in the AWS console is create a Postgres DB instance and make sure it is open to the public (just for this example).

item.title: How to Study for the AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner Exam
item.author: trevor.ryan.mccormick@gmail.com (Trevor McCormick)
item.description: Cloud Foundations The AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner Exam assumes you have some familiarity with cloud concepts. If you’re completely unfamiliar with those, it may benefit you to learn or review some introductory computing concepts. When I was in college, I completed two courses that gave me a great foundation: Stanford CS 101 - Introduction to Computing Principles Harvard CS50 - Introduction to Computer Science This course features one of my favorite professors of all time – David Malan.

item.title: Build a Serverless Hugo Blog on AWS for $0.50 per month
item.author: trevor.ryan.mccormick@gmail.com (Trevor McCormick)
item.description: This post assumes you already have some familiarity with Hugo for building a blog, and you have set up a free-tier AWS account. You don’t have to be an expert at either Hugo or AWS to follow along with the guide below. Really the only requirement is that you’re able to follow the Hugo quick start guide. Below is an AWS architecture diagram I created using diagrams.net, the free version of draw.
